The Asia-Pacific Forum on Sustainable Development (APFSD) aims to provide the global community with the transparency to understand and follow up the progress on the Sustainable Development Goals that we all are striving to achieve by 2023. 40% of food crops are lost through pests and plant diseases. Food waste in the first link of the chain is one of the problems targeted by #SDG12, responsible consumption and production, which aims to halve it by 2030. End food wastage! #Foodwastage #SCP

The 10th #APFSD discussed a long-argued matter on whether #capitalism is a challenge for sustainable consumption and it turned out that over production and wastage are indeed often correlated with commercial advertising and marketing strategies. Aren't we responsible for finding sustainable solutions to solve this wasteful consumption habit? Let's admit it, most of us have already had enough for our basic needs but yet are still demanding more and more for aesthetic purposes. This is a time when we should rethink on our consumption habit and switch to a greener economy. #SDG12 #SustainableConsumption #SustainableProduction #ClearnEnergy

Did you know that today marks the first International Day of Zero Waste? On 14 December 2021, #UNGA adopted a resolution to dedicate every March 30 to #zerowaste. This Day aims to promote #sustainableconsumption and production patterns, support the societal shift towards circularity and raise awareness about how zero-waste initiatives contribute to advancing the #SDGs, especially #SDG11 and #SDG12 #InternationalDayofZeroWaste #wastefreeplanet #zerowasteliving

Last week, our children and teachers engaged in a variety of activities that promote environmental sustainability, including energy and water saving activities. Our eco warriors from M.Y World @ Tampines North and M.Y World @ Sun Natura experimented with various water filtration methods and reused water for their class activities. The little ones also learned about the greenhouse effect and identifying what causes the Earth to be sick. Meanwhile, their peers from M.Y World @ Hougang DewCourt had fun playing Earth Hour bingo with their parents and taking photos of their green activities. The centre commemorated this special event by switching off all electricity for an hour and our children are reminded that it every little helps when it comes to saving planet Earth. A big thank you to all parents who participated in our March sustainability activities! As an advocate for dark sky where we are able to enjoy stargazing, tonight I will take a grassroots action to "Give an Hour for Earth" as called for the 2023 theme of Earth Hour, an annual global campaign hosted by World Wildlife Fund International for raising public awareness of and support to protecting our planet through reducing energy consumption, light pollution and carbon emission. We'll turn off lights at Arcadia EcoHome during 8:80-9:30 pm and walk outdoors for stargazing, smelling floral scents from night blooming plants in our yards and observing activities of moths, lightening bugs & other wildlife around those plants and in the understory & over the forest floor of our homegrown pocket forest, as part of our citizen scientist project works at the EcoHome. Happy Earth Hour 2023! #MyHourForEarth #energysaving #lightpollution #carbonpollution #stargazing #sdg12 #fireflies #moths #pocketforest

Great to meet up with many experts who are working on green projects toward reducing carbon emissions and promoting the green economy during the recent Asian Carbon Conference. One of the experts is Dr. Riza Suarga.
At the conference, our Premier of Sarawak, The Right Honourable Datuk Patinggi Tan Sri (Dr) Abang Haji Abdul Rahman Zohari bin Tun Datuk Abang Haji Openg said Sarawak was committed to its target of net-zero emissions by 2050, largely by increasing its renewable energy capacity and electrifying the transport sector, which opens up opportunities for a green economy.
Opportunities can include investments in renewable energy, sustainable agriculture, eco-tourism, green building, and other areas that promote environmental sustainability and reduce carbon emissions.
The green economy also presents numerous opportunities for businesses and individuals to develop new technologies, create new jobs, and drive economic growth while simultaneously reducing negative environmental impacts.
Some of the benefits of promoting a green economy include reduced greenhouse gas emissions, improved resource efficiency, increased resilience to climate change, improved health and well-being, and the creation of new jobs and economic opportunities.
#sustainability #sdg12 #growth #jobs #opportunities #climatechange #sustainable #sarawak #earthskysea #carboncredits #carbonstorage #borneo #greenprojects #greeneconomy

Today is World Water Day
#WorldWaterDay aims to raise awareness around issues regarding water and its sources. The primary focus of the day is supporting the achievements of Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 6: Water and Sanitation for all by 2030 #sdg6. The theme of World Water Day 2021 is valuing water. 
As UN World Water Development 2021 Report claims, the value of water is about much more than its price. Water has enormous and complex value for our households, food, culture, health, education, economics. #sdg12

We know that #energyefficiency is on everyone's mind at the moment. But what exactly can be done to ensure resource efficiency? 1. Replace obsolete electric appliances with new ones, preferrably those with sustainable or green technology 2. Recycle or reuse products to reduce waste production and resource depletion 3. #SDG12 - Industrial production processes account for a considerable share of the overall pollution in Europe. Hence, a revolutionary change in production and manufacturing could lead to a groundbreaking impact on the environment which is worth the investment

Production systems have considerable economic, environmental and social significance. As of 2020, manufacturing contributes some 20% of European gross value added, employs around 30% of the European workforce and contributes about 25% of the waste, green house gasses and NO2 generated in Europe. If the trend continues, resources from the environment wil be rapidly depleted, not to mention the escalation of greenhouse effect and global warming. Sustainable production should not be just a slogan. Corporates should take concrete actions in transitioning to adopt green energy and environmental friendly materials when manufacturing goods. By 2030 we ought to have #SDG6 #SDG12 and #SDG15 all working in sync to achieve continental water management, so we channel floodwater into being used to rehydrate all of the inhabited continents. The constructed wetlands that Ducks Unlimited has been advocating could help purify and sequester trillions of cubic meters of purified water, and this would be a key factor in restoring ancient forests and replenishing water tables and reservoirs. We have to build solidarity for this kind of adaptation to reality, and it will help safeguard coastlines as well as be a serious help for protection of the ecosystem.

The essence of sustainable consumption and production lies in doing more and better with less - which is also a key principle of SDG number 12: Responsible Consumption and Production. You may be curious, how is this possible? Think about this. When companies adopt green and clean energy, renewable resources, and minimal packaging for their products, financial costs of manufacturing decreases due to decreased needs in expensive fossil fuels, and other material costs. In addition, with less destructive impacts done to the environment, sustainable consumption also ensures the availability of resources in the future generations. #SCP #SDG12

Great to meet up with many experts who are working on green projects toward reducing carbon emissions and promoting the green economy during the recent Asian Carbon Conference. One of the experts is Dr. Riza Suarga.
At the conference, our Premier of Sarawak, The Right Honourable Datuk Patinggi Tan Sri (Dr) Abang Haji Abdul Rahman Zohari bin Tun Datuk Abang Haji Openg said Sarawak was committed to its target of net-zero emissions by 2050, largely by increasing its renewable energy capacity and electrifying the transport sector, which opens up opportunities for a green economy.
Opportunities can include investments in renewable energy, sustainable agriculture, eco-tourism, green building, and other areas that promote environmental sustainability and reduce carbon emissions.
The green economy also presents numerous opportunities for businesses and individuals to develop new technologies, create new jobs, and drive economic growth while simultaneously reducing negative environmental impacts.
Some of the benefits of promoting a green economy include reduced greenhouse gas emissions, improved resource efficiency, increased resilience to climate change, improved health and well-being, and the creation of new jobs and economic opportunities.

Why #design is fundamental to a circular economy? Design determines what we eat, the clothes we wear, the buildings we live and work in, and the systems that deliver food and mobility. Let's rewrite the narrative of our planet with sustainable actions by producing sustainable designs. Multiple approaches can be taken to achieve this. Recycled materials, minimal packaging, quality products and reusable parts are elements that we may consider when thinking of contributing to circular economy. #circulareconomy #sustainableliving #responsibleconsumption #sdg12

For decades we have been calling out the importance to #recycle and #reuse but why are these actually important to the environment? First, by circulating the existing resources, we reduce the need to exploit more from the environment and its biodiversity. Second, recycling and reusing lead to a lesser amount of waste generated and lesser waste means lesser greenhouse gases produced at landfills and waste incineration. There are multifold benefits behind sustainable living. Together, we can make a world of difference through sustainable living.  #sustainableliving #environment #climateaction #sdg12 #sdg13

Sustainable resources are natural resources that can be replenished or regenerated at a rate that is equal to or greater than their rate of consumption. TRANSFORMING BANANA TREE WASTE INTO TEXTILES - Absorbs better than cotton. Needs less water and dye for production, Banana Fibres can be converted into fashion and textile products like mats, rugs, hair extensions and so on. Banana textiles have been in use in countries like Japan since the 13th Century but its use declined with the rise of silk and cotton from China and India. Since fruit can only be harvested from banana trees once in their lifetime, farmers often discard  or burn the banana stem after the bananas are harvested thereby leading to waste or air pollution. Let's not put the remaining parts of banana trees to waste. #WasteManagement #ResourcePlanning #SustainableProduction #SCP #SDG12

In a world where people are dying from hunger, one-third of all food produced is thrown away every year. Not only does food waste exacerbate food insecurity, but it also causes severe damage to our environment. When we throw away food, we also throw away the precious resources that went into producing this food. This includes the use of land and natural resources, the social cost to the environment, and our biodiversity. In addition to that, these resources decompose in landfills and emit methane, which is even more damaging than carbon dioxide in trapping heat in the atmosphere. Yes -- Greenhouse Effect. Now rethink on our consumption behavior. Stop Food Wastage! #foodwaste #biodiversity #sustainableconsumption #sdg12 #worldhunger

Do you know that food waste generates 8% of total annual greenhouse gas emissions? And most of us do not know about why is it so critical to end food wastage. Here are some of the damages of food wastage. Agriculture accounts for 70% of the water used throughout the world. By putting food to waste, we are wasting the precious source of water which could cultivate lives. Second, when food is left to rot in our landfills, it subsequently releases methane, a powerful greenhouse gas twenty-five times stronger than carbon dioxide. Worse, methane released from food waste contributes up to 20% of greenhouse gases emission, thus causing astonishing impacts on climate change. Now is it still 'JUST SOME FOOD'? #FoodWaste #Consumption #SDG12 #ClimateChange

Earth Overshoot Day #EarthOvershootDay is computed by dividing the planet‚Äôs biocapacity (the amount of ecological resources Earth is able to generate that year), by humanity‚Äôs Ecological Footprint (humanity‚Äôs demand for that year), and multiplying by 365, the number of days in a year. To sum it up, we should work on moving the date by encouraging sustainble consumption and cutting down the use of resources.
